title: Dangers of Poor Sleep
content: Poor sleep can increase the risk of Alzheimer’s, negatively affect mental health, and impair memory. It can also increase the risk of heart disease, cancer, and disrupt sexual function. Poor sleep can have penetrating effects from metabolism to genetics.

title: Sleep and Immune Function
content: Sleep is crucial for proper immune function. Good sleep hygiene is important for maintaining a healthy immune system.

title: Sleep-related Questions and Answers
content: DEC2 is a genetic mutation that produces a short sleeping phenotype. The best position to sleep in is on your back for spinal alignment, unless you suffer from sleep apnea or heavy snoring. The optimal room temperature and body temperature for the best sleep is yet to be determined. Caffeine can affect sleep. Sexual activity can relate to sleep quality. Napping can be beneficial if done correctly. Sleep deprivation can be harmful, especially for new parents. Understanding your sleep chronotype can help manage sleep. Alcohol can disrupt sleep. Postmenopausal women can manage their sleep problems with and without hormone replacement therapy. Sleep apnea can be diagnosed and treated. Poor sleep can speed up the aging process. Medicated sleep may not be as beneficial as natural sleep. Vivid dreaming can disrupt the sleep cycle. Fasting and time-restricted eating can affect sleep.

title: Sleep and Aging
content: As we age, we may not be able to generate the amount of sleep we need due to brain atrophy, particularly in the deep sleep generating areas. This can lead to less sleep or poorer quality sleep as we get older.

title: DEC2 Mutation and Sleep
content: People with the DEC2 mutation are short sleepers. They tend to be efficient deep sleepers but get less REM sleep. The health consequences of having the DEC2 mutation are not yet known.

title: Sleeping Positions and the Glymphatic System
content: The glymphatic system is a cleansing system for the brain that washes away metabolic toxins and byproducts during sleep. There is some evidence from animal studies that side sleeping allows the glymphatic system greater clearance capacity than any other sleeping position.

title: Sleep Divorce
content: About 40% of people do not sleep in the same location as their partner. Of the remaining 60%, about 20-30% go to bed with their partner at night, but wake up in a different location in the morning. A 'sleep divorce' can increase the quality of sleep, which can improve sex hormones in both males and females, and improve the quality of the relationship.

title: Sleeping with Children
content: Sleeping with children can disrupt your own sleep. It's also difficult to train them to gain the confidence to sleep by themselves, a skill they will need throughout their lives.

title: Ideal Pillow
content: There is no scientific data on the ideal type of pillow. However, it could be possible to find the right pillow by using three-dimensional imaging to understand your head mass, body type, and sleep preferences.

title: Hammock Sleeping and Rocking
content: There isn't much data on hammock sleeping, but there is evidence that the nature of rocking can help people fall asleep faster and have greater amounts of deep sleep.

title: Optimal Room Temperature for Sleep
content: The optimal room temperature for sleep is between 65-67 degrees. However, this can vary from person to person. Warming up your extremities can help you fall asleep faster, and then you need to get cold to stay asleep during the night.

title: Humidifiers and Sleep
content: There is little data on whether humidifiers help with sleep. The few studies that exist do not suggest that humidity makes a difference.

title: High Altitudes and Sleep
content: Data suggests that at altitudes above 5,000-6,000 feet, people wake up more frequently and have less amount of non-rapid eye movement sleep and less deep non-REM sleep quantity.

title: Weighted Blankets
content: There is no good data at the moment on the efficacy of weighted blankets. However, if people subjectively feel like their sleep is improving, that is a good thing.

title: Caffeine and Sleep
content: Caffeine can reduce the amount of deep sleep quality by about 20%. This reduction is equivalent to aging by 25 years.

title: Sexual Activity and Sleep Quality
content: For most people, sex that results in an orgasm produces better quality of sleep. This is because it moves us into the parasympathetic state of the nervous system, which is a quiet, restful state. It also results in a deceleration of the heart rate and a reduction in cortisol, which is the enemy of sleep at night.

title: Sleeping in Two Phases
content: There is no evidence to suggest that humans are supposed to sleep in two phases. It’s more likely that we were designed to sleep 6.5-7 hrs at night and take an afternoon nap. This is common in hunter gatherer tribes.

title: Ideal Duration of a Nap
content: The ideal duration of a nap depends on what you’re asking of the nap. A 90 minute nap will give you one full sleep cycle and allow for some REM sleep. If you want to simply get rid of some fatigue and sleepiness, a 15-20 minute nap will be enough. Try to avoid waking up after about 45 minutes as you may suffer what’s called sleep inertia, which is where you may actually feel even worse.

title: Benefits and Drawbacks of Napping
content: Benefits of napping may include improvement in learning and memory, and cardiovascular function. However, throughout the day you are building up the sleepiness chemical called adenosine. If you nap, you release some of that pressure which may make it harder for you to fall asleep at night.

title: Advice for New Parents Dealing with Sleep Deprivation
content: New parents, especially moms, with young babies should try to nap when the child is napping. The nights will be rough and disruptive so you’ll have enough sleep pressure even if you are napping several times a day.

title: Understanding Your Sleep Chronotype
content: Your sleep chronotype is genetically set. However, your sleep timing and hours needed will change from childhood, to teen years, to adulthood. Then as we get into our elder years we regress to childhood hours, go to bed early, wake up early.

title: Effects of Alcohol on Sleep
content: If you drink too much, there is probably nothing you can do that night to make sure your sleep isn’t wrecked. The best thing to do is expect a bad night of sleep and plan accordingly tomorrow.

title: Managing Sleep Problems in Postmenopausal Women
content: Many women after menopause see a decline in their sleep quality and quantity. Data suggest that hormone replacement therapy (HRT) combined with melatonin has some efficacy. You combine those two and sleep seems to be improved.

title: Wim Hof’s Breathing Method and Sleep
content: There is currently no evidence to suggest that a daily practice of Wim Hof’s breathing method could help or hinder quality of sleep.

title: Feeling More Tired the More You Sleep
content: If you feel more tired the more you sleep, it could be because you’re still trying to sleep off the debt that you’ve accumulated. However, if this has been going on for five or six months, it could be because you’re not sleeping at the right phase.

title: Understanding Sleep Apnea
content: Sleep apnea is a condition where your airways collapse, either partially or fully, which obstructs your ability to breath. It is the most underdiagnosed sleep disorder and can be fatal. If you think you might have sleep apnea, take the Stop-Bang Questionnaire and find yourself a board certified sleep medicine doctor.

title: Apneic Hypoxemic Index vs Oxygen Desaturation Index
content: The Oxygen Desaturation Index (ODI) with a 4% cutoff is preferred. Mortality data indicates that more than ~25 4% ODIs per hour is a significant predictor of mortality. The Apnea Hypopnea Index looks at the number of times that you have a true apneic event where you have a cessation of breathing. A moderate degree of apnea would be a cessation of breath between 10 to 15 per hour.

title: Sleep Trackers and Oxygen Saturation
content: Fitbit devices have the capacity built in to detect oxygen saturation but may not have unlocked it yet. There are concerns about the accuracy of such measurements.

title: Sleep Eating
content: Sleep eating is a real condition and is part of a set of conditions that we call parasomnias. These are things that happen around sleep, not necessarily during sleep itself. Parasomnias typically happen from deep sleep when you get a jolt of the sympathetic nervous system activity. A more rare variation is sleep eating. There’s not too much we can do, unfortunately. There may be a few pharmacological approaches out there but not great treatment outcomes right now.

title: Improving Sleep in Society
content: A public health campaign needs to be the first step at the government level. Institutions should also promote better sleep. In school, we get lectures on safe sex, drink and driving, etc. Where was that lecture for sleep education?

title: Retrospective Damage and Prospective Benefit of Sleep
content: If I put you on one night of four hours of sleep, I can drop your natural killer cell count on average for this group by about 70%. The following day after that short sleep, your vulnerability to cancer is presumably going to be increased because of that drop in NK cells. Now, getting lots and lots of sleep the following night is not going to go back in time and bend the arrow of time back on itself and wash away that cancer risk.

title: Poor Sleep and Aging
content: Less sleep is associated with an increase in biomarkers of age. Aging causes poor sleep, but poor sleep also causes aging. The question then becomes… Is the traffic flowing more dominantly in one direction than another?

title: Medicated Sleep vs No Sleep
content: For someone struggling with severe insomnia, it is a tough question whether it is better to get almost no sleep or to take an antihistamine or mild benzos as a sleep aid. People very quickly build a tolerance to antihistamines and then they can typically have rebound insomnia when they come off of antihistamines and/or benzos.

title: Vivid Dreaming and Sleep Cycle
content: Vivid dreams do not seem to disrupt sleep in terms of quantity of quality (even though they may feel sort of exhausting). Trauma dreams (i.e., in PTSD patients) do, in fact, disrupt sleep.

title: Binaural Beats and Sleep
content: There is no good scientific studies that have really demonstrated efficacy of using “binaural beats” to induce better deep sleep.

title: Fasting and Time-Restricted Eating on Sleep
content: Fasting, from an evolutionary perspective, would reduce our sleep demand to give us more time to forage for food. But in Peter’s experience with fasting, he finds it produces an amazing state of sleep (albeit slightly less duration) but better in quality.

title: Polyphasic Sleep
content: The Uberman schedule of sleep is a version of polyphasic sleep where sleep for short bursts (45-90 mins) then be awake for a couple hours and then just cycle on and off throughout the day. There is no good evidence in adults that that is at all how we should be sleeping.
